information:
Six Democrats are running in the June 17 primary for Virginia lieutenant governor: Alex Bastani, State Sen. Ghazala F. Hashmi, Babur B. Lateef, State Sen. Aaron R. Rouse, Victor Salgado, and former Richmond Mayor Levar Stoney. While the candidates agree on many core policies, such as repealing Virginia's right-to-work law and increasing the minimum wage, they differ on specific issues like gaming and education. Rouse, a former Virginia Beach City Council member, has sponsored legislation to strengthen protections for renters and to create a regulatory framework for the state's recreational cannabis market. Stoney has positioned himself as both business-friendly and committed to helping families. Hashmi, a former professor, highlights her six years of experience in the Senate.

According to campaign finance records reported around May 1, 2025, Levar Stoney led the six-candidate field in fundraising, having raised approximately $1.4 million. State Senators Aaron Rouse and Ghazala Hashmi were also among the fundraising leaders. In late May, Carl Eggleston, a former candidate for lieutenant governor and the first African American to be elected to the Farmville Town Council, endorsed Levar Stoney, citing his executive experience. Reports also indicate Stoney has the backing of several Richmond-area elected officials, while Rouse has support from labor and progressive-issue groups.

An internal poll conducted for the Levar Stoney campaign in March 2025 showed Stoney leading the primary field with 16% support, followed by Aaron Rouse at 10%, and Ghazala Hashmi at 8%; 63% of voters were undecided. Geographically, Rouse's political base is in the Hampton Roads area (Virginia Beach/Norfolk), while Stoney's is in the Richmond metro area. Northern Virginia represents the largest voting bloc in the primary but does not have a candidate from the region.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: About 3 weeks (primary is June 17, 2025; unofficial results likely same night)
forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — Levar Stoney remains the narrow front-runner and wins a low-plurality primary
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Stoney leverages his fundraising edge to dominate late TV/digital in the DC and Richmond markets, consolidates undecideds (especially in Northern Virginia), and benefits from Hashmi splitting the Richmond-area reform/professor/Asian American vote. Rouse runs up margins in Hampton Roads but underperforms elsewhere and finishes second.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Rouse maximizes Hampton Roads turnout, union and progressive groups deliver superior GOTV statewide, and late advertising plus mail lifts his name ID in Northern Virginia. With Stoney and Hashmi dividing the Richmond base, Rouse wins with a mid-to-high 20s plurality.
forecast.rationale:
Baseline: With ~21 days left and limited public polling, money, name recognition, and endorsements loom large in a low-turnout, multi-candidate Democratic primary decided by a plurality. The research indicates: six candidates; Stoney led fundraising (~$1.4M by ~May 1) and had a March internal poll at 16% vs. Rouse 10% and Hashmi 8% with 63% undecided; Stoney has Richmond-area elected support; Rouse has labor/progressive backing; Northern Virginia is the largest voting bloc without a high-profile hometown candidate. These factors collectively make Stoney the status quo favorite.

Why not higher than my estimate for Rouse: Stoney’s cash advantage likely funds broad DC-market advertising (critical with many undecideds in NoVA), plus he has executive experience and establishment backing. Hashmi’s presence could further fragment any anti-Stoney vote in the Richmond region. With such a high undecided share as of March, late persuasion via paid media typically benefits the best-funded campaign.

Why not lower: Plurality rules in a six-way field raise volatility and lower the bar to win. Rouse has a clear geographic base (Hampton Roads), credible fundraising, and strong labor/progressive organizational support that can matter disproportionately in low-turnout contests. With Stoney and Hashmi competing around Richmond, a path opens for Rouse if he extends beyond his base and performs adequately in NoVA.

Update triggers upward for Rouse: credible public polling showing him tied or leading; visible, well-funded ad buys in the DC market; major late endorsements (statewide figures or influential unions) and evidence of strong early vote/turnout surges in Hampton Roads; negative news or stumbles for Stoney.

Update triggers downward: new polling with Stoney opening a clear lead; cash-on-hand data showing a decisive late-money gap favoring Stoney; major statewide endorsements for Stoney; strong Richmond and NoVA consolidation behind Stoney; indications that Hashmi is surging and siphoning enough anti-Stoney votes to keep Rouse in second.

Weighting the slow-to-change status quo (fundraising/endorsements advantage and early lead) while allowing for multi-candidate uncertainty yields a modest underdog position for Rouse.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will Aaron Rouse win the Democratic primary for lieutenant governor of Virginia in June 2025?

Question background:
Ballotpedia: [Virginia lieutenant gubernatorial election, 2025 (June 17 Democratic primary)](https://ballotpedia.org/Virginia_lieutenant_gubernatorial_election,_2025_(June_17_Democratic_primary))


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if Aaron Rouse wins the 2025 Democratic primary for Lieutenant Governor of Virginia, according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions).

The Democratic primary election is currently scheduled for June 17, 2025. If there is no Democratic primary held before June 30, 2025, the question will be **annulled**.


Your research assistant's report says:
Six Democrats are running in the June 17 primary for Virginia lieutenant governor: Alex Bastani, State Sen. Ghazala F. Hashmi, Babur B. Lateef, State Sen. Aaron R. Rouse, Victor Salgado, and former Richmond Mayor Levar Stoney. While the candidates agree on many core policies, such as repealing Virginia's right-to-work law and increasing the minimum wage, they differ on specific issues like gaming and education. Rouse, a former Virginia Beach City Council member, has sponsored legislation to strengthen protections for renters and to create a regulatory framework for the state's recreational cannabis market. Stoney has positioned himself as both business-friendly and committed to helping families. Hashmi, a former professor, highlights her six years of experience in the Senate.

According to campaign finance records reported around May 1, 2025, Levar Stoney led the six-candidate field in fundraising, having raised approximately $1.4 million. State Senators Aaron Rouse and Ghazala Hashmi were also among the fundraising leaders. In late May, Carl Eggleston, a former candidate for lieutenant governor and the first African American to be elected to the Farmville Town Council, endorsed Levar Stoney, citing his executive experience. Reports also indicate Stoney has the backing of several Richmond-area elected officials, while Rouse has support from labor and progressive-issue groups.

An internal poll conducted for the Levar Stoney campaign in March 2025 showed Stoney leading the primary field with 16% support, followed by Aaron Rouse at 10%, and Ghazala Hashmi at 8%; 63% of voters were undecided. Geographically, Rouse's political base is in the Hampton Roads area (Virginia Beach/Norfolk), while Stoney's is in the Richmond metro area. Northern Virginia represents the largest voting bloc in the primary but does not have a candidate from the region.

Today is 2025-05-27.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
